Yes, there are many citizen science programs focused on monitoring ocean ecosystems that you can get involved in!

One such program is the Ocean Observers program, which is run by the Australian Marine Mammal Centre. This program allows volunteers to monitor marine mammals and seabirds along the Australian coast, providing valuable information on their distribution and abundance.

Another program is the Marine Debris Tracker, which allows volunteers to track and report marine debris found on beaches and coastlines worldwide. The data collected through this program can be used to identify hotspots of marine debris accumulation and inform pollution reduction efforts.

You may also be interested in the Sea Turtle Watch program, which is run by the Loggerhead Marinelife Center in Florida. This program trains volunteers to monitor sea turtle nesting habitats and assists with conservation efforts to protect nesting sites.

In addition, the Citizen Science for the Ocean program, run by the Nature Conservancy, provides a list of various citizen science projects related to ocean and coastal conservation that you can get involved in.

These are just a few examples of citizen science programs focused on ocean ecosystems. There are many more programs out there, so I encourage you to do some research and find one that interests you!
